newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel in loan deal with 21-bank syndicate.
newsitem.headline: Israel in loan deal with 21-bank syndicate.

text.p: Israel has taken out a 1.1 billion French franc seven-year loan with an international syndicate of 21 banks, said Israel's Bank Hapoalim which helped arrange the deal.

The facility carries an interest rate of 0.25 percent over Libor for the first five years and 0.3 percent over Libor for the next two years, Bank Hapoalim, Israel's biggest commercial bank, said in a statement on Sunday.
The last such loan, arranged for a five-year period for DM 350 million a year ago, carried rates of 0.45 percent and 0.5 percent over Libor, the statement said.
Bank Hapoalim said it completed the loan, denominated in francs, together with Banque Nationale de Paris, Bayerische Landesbank, the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and NatWest Markets.
It said the facility, part of a multi-year programme by the Israeli Finance Ministry to raise long-term foreign currency financing, was signed last week in London.
The loan involved a syndicate of 21 banks from Austria, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Britain, the United States and Singapore.
"This represents a real vote of confidence in Israel by the international banking community," the statement quoted Israel's accountant general, Shai Talmon, as saying at the signing ceremony.
